text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.)

Name THOMAS ROY BROWN RIDGE M.D
Address 2905 MCGALLUM AVE, REGINA
Birthplace BROADVIEW ASSINIBOIA

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? Born 1891
Where did you set up housekeeping? n/a
Where had you been living before that? n/a
For how many people did you prepare meals? n/a
How far was it to your nearest store? 3 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Usually weekly
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Tea, coffee, sugar, salt, baking powder, soda, dried fruit.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Our own
In what quantities did you buy it? 10 lbs at a time (in rough half-packs)
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? don't know
How much did you use graham flour? Don't know
Whole wheat flour? n/a
Was flour milled locally? Yes How far away? 24 miles What year? 1917
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Can't say
What other grain products did you use? Oatmeal, cracked wheat
Cornmeal? n/a Whole Wheat? n/a Farina? n/a
Other? n/a
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? n/a
How did you grind it? Ground at the flour mill
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: THOMAS R.O.X. BROWNIDGE M.D.
Address: 4835 MCGALLUM AVE, REGINA
Birthplace: BROADVIEW, ASSINIBOIA

1. INTERCUTARY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1891
Where did you set up housekeeping? Regina
Where had you been living before that? Regina
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
How far was it to your nearest store? Usually nearby
How often could a visit be made to the store? Usually nearby
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Groceries, sugar, salt, flour, tea, coffee, sugar, salt, flour, tea, coffee

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? American
In what quantities did you buy it? 10 lbs. per week (25 lbs. per month)
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 75¢
How much did you use graham flour? 75¢
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 20 miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 5¢
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, buckwheat
Cornmeal? Yes
Other? No
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? Hand mill
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 50 lb. each.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.00.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? 

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lb.

At what price? 

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? 

butter? 

eggs? 

What was the price of butter? 

of eggs? 

Did you pack eggs for winter? 

how? 

Did you make butter? 

cheese? 

What kind of cheese? 

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? 

How did you get fresh meat? 

How often did you get fresh meat? 

How did you preserve meat? 

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? 

If so what year was it organized? 

Did you use game? 

What kinds? 

For how long? 

What part did fish play in the family diet? 

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? 

Kinds?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? $4.00. (Dec.)

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.50.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? (Blank)

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lbs.

At what price? (Blank)

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Used milk from local farms.

What was the price of butter? $1.25 per lb.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

That kind of cheese? (Blank)

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? (Blank)

How did you get fresh meat? Purchased at butcher shop or locally raised.

How often did you get fresh meat? Weekly.

How did you preserve meat? (Blank)

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized? (Blank)

Did you use game? (Blank)

For how long? 20-30 years.

What part did fish play in the family diet? (Blank)

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? (Blank)

Kinds? (Blank)
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon. At what price? n/a

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground.

Price? n/a. What other beverages were used? n/a

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 25¢

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from? Gardens.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1891 Cabbage 1891 Carrots 1891 Onions 1891

Turnips 1891 Beets 1891

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? n/a

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? In bulk.

What weight? Can't say. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes.

What was the price of prunes? Can't say.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)

Apples, apricots, raisins and currants.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No.

Peas? No. Corn? No. Beans? No. Saskatoons? No.

Other foods? No.

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? About 1904.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? About 1907.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? About 1905.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? No.

To what extent? n/a

Did you make your own vinegar? Yes. Remember my mother having what was called "mush" for making vinegar but don't remember what else was used because cider was available.
6. BEVERAGES
What kind of tea did you buy? Black, Red, Green, etc. At what price per lb.? $1.25
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground
Price? $1.50
What other beverages were used? None

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS
What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? $4.00
If not, where from? Grocer
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of? 1941
Potatoes 15¢/lb. Cabbage 18¢/lb. Carrots 18¢/lb. Onions 18¢/lb.
Turnips 15¢/lb. Beets 15¢/lb.

In what quantities did you buy navy beans? 7 lbs.
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? In bulk
What weight? 3 lbs.
How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? By box
What was the price of prunes? 5¢/lb.
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? Apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants, or others

8. PRESERVING
In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes
Fruits? Peaches, apples, pears, apricots, plums, prunes, etc.
Other foods? Beans, corn, etc.
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1941
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1941
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1941
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes

To what extent? None
Did you make your own vinegar? Yes
How much was your method of making vinegar? 5 gallons
Did you make your own cider? Yes
How much was your cider? 5 gallons

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? .................................................. my mother made her own

Did you make yeast for your own use? ........................................... yes

Using starter? .................................................................................. yes

Using hops? ...................................................................................... no

Salt rising? ....................................................................................... no

Did you buy baking powder? ............................................................. yes

Baking soda? .................................................................................... yes

Cream of tartar? ............................................................................... yes

Did you make your own baking powder? ........................................... yes

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? "my mother made her own"

Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes

Using starter? Yes

Using hops? Yes

Salt rising? Yes

Did you buy baking powder? Yes

Baking soda? Yes

Did you make your own baking powder? Yes

Cream of tartar? Yes

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) From our well.

How far was this water from your home? In the yard.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) By pails.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

This same well is still in use.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout)

How far was this water from your home?

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Ohio River Well in field near me.
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Yes, my mother made her own.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Crown.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? From local lumberyards.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No, always used a stove.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Buck Stove Co.

What year was it purchased? Before 1900. Price? Don't know.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron and tin, non-homemade.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) China, earthenware, enamel ware.

When did you first see enamel ware? Can't remember.

Aluminum? About 1903.
6.

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use lye? If yes, what kind?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocers handle?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days?

Where did you get your fuel?

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth—in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made?

What year was it purchased?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware?

Aluminum?
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

At first wrappings were plain paper, later twisted paper, later
cellophane etc.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast (Summer): oatmeal porridge, hot tea, fried eggs, toast, jam.
(Summer): milk the same, but breakfast added at noon.

Dinner (Summer): corned beef or ham, potatoes, lettuce, radishes, onions, pie or pudding, and some homemade salad.
(Summer): beef or ham, chicken, potatoes, turnips, cabbage, dessert, milk the same as on summer.

Supper (Summer): eggs or creamed meat, potatoes, bread and butter.
(Cooking): coffee, pudding, fruit, tea.

(Summer): fish meal, potatoes, cake or custard or hardtack, tea.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? .......
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Can't say.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Our family never was but I have known families that
outsided for the winter on buckwheat and rye.
16. TRAVEL AND CONTAINERS

Describe any changes which you recall in the transportation and containers used with the food you purchased (give dates where applicable) and containers received.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast (summer): Oatmeal, toast, jam, coffee, milk.

Breakfast (winter): Oatmeal, toast, jam, coffee, milk.

Lunch: Ham sandwich, potato salad, tomato soup.

Dinner: Beef stew, carrots, potatoes, bread, milk.

Supper: Chicken, mashed potatoes, green beans, bread, milk.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the date.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Our family never went back to pioneer homesteading out west for the winter on buckwheat and rolled oats.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

This is a bit out of my line.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I would say about 1910 though it was a very gradual process.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

What I have said about the prominence of Prairie Chickens as meat in our winter diet in early years is not unusually applicable. Some people obtained the chickens and just used the breast and perhaps legs but my mother always pickled them, stuffed them and cooked them with a slip of fat pork tied on each side of the breast and they were really splendid, and never tired of them.

Storing vegetables was always a problem. Potatoes would have to be packed and a couple of times before spring and nothing else packed out also sprouts excepted. But potatoes usually kept well and cabbages would usually get soft about February. Carrots usually kept fairly well but tubers were hazardous.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

This is a list of my list.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

Successful Day at least 1910 when I was a young graduate physician.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality methods of merchandising, prices, problems, plans of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed.)

When I began to buy the provisions to help pioneer

Chickens as much as our health allowed, we purchased them from the local market. They were always fresh and well cared for.

Local and nearby towns would have a shop or two that sold the goods.

During the winter, we would usually order our supplies from the local store.

We packed food in cans and jars, preserving and storing them.

Packing would usually be done in January, February, March, and April.

Supplying milk and eggs was also very important.
